questions.question: This UNESCO World Heritage Site, known for its immense collection of rock carvings, depicts life from a civilization over 3,000 years ago in the Arabian Desert.
questions.context: It was the first World Heritage Site in Saudi Arabia and its carvings are from the Nabatean civilization, the same builders as Petra.

questions.question: This modern architectural marvel is known for its sail-like design and is located in a metropolis famous for its iconic skyline, having opened in 1973.
questions.context: Designed by Danish architect JÃ¸rn Utzon, it hosts over 1,500 performances annually showcasing a range of art forms.

questions.question: This historical battle site in Europe was the location of a significant 1805 military engagement where Napoleon's forces defeated the Russian and Austrian armies.
questions.context: Also known as the Battle of the Three Emperors, it is often regarded as Napoleon's greatest victory.

questions.question: Renowned for its vast collection of art and antiquities, this museum features works like the 'Mona Lisa' and is housed in a former royal palace, receiving millions of visitors each year.
questions.context: With over 380,000 objects and an area of 782,910 square feet, it is the world's largest art museum.

questions.question: This ancient ruin in South America stands high in the Andes and was built in the 15th century, known for its agricultural terraces, intricate stone buildings, and stunning vista.
questions.context: Often referred to as the 'Lost City of the Incas', it was rediscovered by Hiram Bingham in 1911 and is an icon of Inca civilization.
